0.00.text: In the year 1014, Byzantine Emperor Basil the Second defeated the Bulgarian army and captured 15 thousand prisoners.

9.30.text: He could've killed them, but he had a different idea.

13.12.text: He wanted to weaken his opponents for decades to come.

16.76.text: So he ordered that 99 out of every 100 prisoners be blinded.

22.08.text: The 100th to be spared one eye to guide the rest back home,

26.30.text: forcing their communities to care for them for the rest of their lives.

30.42.text: Today, humans are subject to an attack just as cynical as this by a league of supervillians called NTDs.

39.06.text: One in seven humans on the planet suffers from one or more NTDs, more than the entire population of Europe.

47.30.text: They do unimaginable damage, by crippling countless people,

51.50.text: they destroy billions of dollars in income each year, weaken communities, and slow progress.

57.48.text: What are these monsters straight out of a horror movie, seeking to wreak havoc on our species?

72.44.text: NTDs are caused by a vast range of different parasites such as worms, amoebae, bacteria, or viruses.

79.78.text: The symptoms they cause are just as diverse and truly the stuff of nightmares.

84.98.text: Some, like hookworms, compete with children's brains and bodies for nutrition,

92.80.text: Some NTDs cause blindness as the result of awful eye infections.

97.12.text: Other parasites confine patients to bed for months, and damage internal organs, often shortening lifespans drastically.

104.76.text: Yet others cause horrible disfigurements that lead to social stigma, a life lived in shame, and unemployment.

111.26.text: There are also a few that are incredibly agonizing. They cause continuous itching, or horrible pain.

118.76.text: In fact, let's introduce you to one of them: Dracun culiasis.

122.84.text: If you accidentally drink water infected by it, you won't notice anything for a year.

128.38.text: Until one day, you suddenly see a blister on your leg.

132.46.text: The worm breaks out of the skin to release new larvae.

136.24.text: The only way to remove it is to slowly pull it out of your leg, centimeter by centimeter, over the course of several weeks,

143.88.text: because Dracun culiasis is now up to a meter long.

147.16.text: We can all agree that we should kill such parasites with fire.

151.16.text: That's why we declared war on them, pleading to eradicate most of them by 2020, and we tried doing that very hard.

158.54.text: In 1985, there were 3.5 million cases of Dracun culiasis all over the world.

167.68.text: We killed 99.999% of these little monsters.

172.46.text: It will be the first parasite we eradicate for good very soon.

177.28.text: So, even if they don't generate big headlines like Ebola did, actually, amazing things have happened when it comes to NTDs.

184.78.text: All NTDs have one thing in common:

187.42.text: they preferably attack humans who live in the most isolated communities, and who are least able to defend themselves.

193.38.text: There are villages that are 500 kilometers from the nearest health facility, with no roads anywhere.

198.56.text: So even if a remedy is available, what if it means going on an odyssey to get it to the patients?

204.64.text: This called for an attack using brute force.

208.16.text: To stamp out NTDs once and for all, what's possibly the biggest medical program in human history was launched, unmatched in scale.

215.64.text: Organizations from all fields are working together right now to eliminate ten of these NTDs forever.

223.62.text: Ironically, every NTD is, in fact, preventable or treatable.

227.78.text: But most of them can only be controlled by giving medicine to every person in all high-risk areas.

234.18.text: That means millions and millions of doses of medicine, often for several NTDs at a time, over the course of years, in countries where there is no infrastructure.

243.50.text: Governments and health organizations just couldn't do that by themselves.

248.36.text: Here, humanity got an opportunity to show off what the industrialized production of medicine can achieve.

255.44.text: The pharma industry stepped in to distribute the necessary drugs for free, and promised to keep doing it until those ten diseases are gone.

263.86.text: By 2020, nearly $18 billion worth of drugs will have been distributed, the largest drug donation the world has ever seen.

271.82.text: They also helped make sure the drugs actually get to where they're needed.

277.62.text: In 2015 alone, these treatments reached over 850 million people, more than the population of the EU and the US combined.

289.62.text: Hundreds of millions of people overcoming extremely destructive diseases, in an unprecedented act of cooperation doesn't.

296.62.text: Stories like this one are not told often enough.

299.54.text: Good things happen all the time, moving humanity closer to a future with no suffering.

305.62.text: So, if you or one of your friends are in need of uplifting news, share this video with them.

311.02.text: We, as a species, really can do great things with no other motivation than to help each other.

317.04.text: It's good to remember that from time to time.
